questions.text: A 33-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 1, comes to the OPD for a prenatal visit at 20 weeks gestation. She feels well and reports experiencing fetal movements. The patient and her husband have no medical conditions, but their first child, a 3-year-old boy, was born with spina bifida. Physical examination is unremarkable, and uterine size is in accordance with dates established using ultrasonography. The patient is worried that the fetus may develop the same birth defect as her first child. The inheritance pattern of her child's birth defect is most similar to which of the following conditions?
Which of the following is NOT a risk factor for epithelial ovarian cancer?

A 28-year-old man is evaluated for abnormal movements of the hands and face. The patient reports that he started experiencing involuntary grimacing a year ago, which has gradually worsened. He is taking a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor for major depression but has not taken any antipsychotic medications. His 52-year-old father was diagnosed with an inherited movement disorder 2 months ago. Physical examination shows normal strength and normal deep tendon reflexes. No sensory deficits are noted. Which of the following best explains the difference in disease presentation between this patient and his father?

choices.text: Sexual abstinence for 3 months and avoid pregnancy for a year
Sexual abstinence for 3 weeks and avoid pregnancy for 6 months
Sexual abstinence for 6 weeks and avoid pregnancy for a year
Sexual abstinence for 6 months and avoid pregnancy for 6 years

questions.text: What would be your advice for a patient who has undergone a vesicovaginal fistula repair?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Sexual abstinence for 3 months and avoid pregnancy for a year

questions.solution: Ans. A. Herpenden calliper for skin fold thickness

questions.text: Which one among the following has the lowest risk of perinatal transmission?

choices.text: Corticosteroids followed by induction of labor

questions.text: A 23-year-old primi came to the emergency department at 35 weeks of pregnancy with pedal edema and BP of 140/90 mmHg. The urine dipstick was 2+. Her investigations are listed below. Hb – 9.2g%, RBS – 123, SGOT – 250, SGPT – 300, Creatinine – 0.7, platelet – 50000. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Induction of labor

 

Diagnosis: Severe preeclampsia with features of HELLP syndrome.

 

Justification:

 

  • BP ≥140/90 mmHg with proteinuria (2+) → Preeclampsia.
  • AST/ALT markedly elevated → Hepatic involvement.
  • Platelet count <100,000/mm³ → Thrombocytopenia.
  • Together, these findings fulfill criteria for HELLP syndrome:
  • Hemolysis
  • Elevated Liver enzymes
  • Low Platelets

 

Stepwise Clinical Reasoning:

 

  1. Gestational age = 35 weeks (near term).
  2. HELLP syndrome = life-threatening complication of preeclampsia.
  3. The only definitive treatment = delivery, regardless of gestational age.
  4. Induction of labor is preferred if: Cervix is favorable. Mother and fetus are stable

 

Therefore, Immediate delivery (induction of labor) is indicated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Corticosteroids followed by induction of labor: Steroids for fetal lung maturity are useful <34 weeks. Here, the patient is 35 weeks — lungs are mature enough, and delaying delivery increases maternal risk.

 

Option C. Start Labetalol and immediate LSCS: 

 

  • LSCS (Caesarean section) is indicated only if There is fetal distress. Unfavorable cervix with urgent need for delivery. Failed induction
  • Here, BP is only mildly elevated, and patient can be induced safely.

 

Option D. Induction at 37 weeks: Waiting is unsafe in HELLP syndrome — it can rapidly progress to DIC, liver rupture, or maternal death. Delivery must be done immediately, not delayed.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the clinic for evaluation of muscle weakness. The patient has a history of seizures. Examination shows decreased strength in the upper and lower extremities on the left compared to the right. Laboratory evaluation shows increased serum lactate levels both after exercise and at rest. His older sister is affected by the same disorder, but she displays very few symptoms. Which of the following is the most likely pedigree chart in the following?
As per the WHO Labor Care Guide, at what cervical dilatation should active phase begin?

questions.text:
A 37-year-old woman comes to the OPD for evaluation of abnormal vaginal discharge. She noticed increased clear, watery vaginal discharge 4 months ago and now has intermenstrual bleeding. She reports no pruritus or dysuria. Blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg and pulse is 88/min. PS examination is shown. The vaginal mucosa is not erythematous and has no lesions.

 

The uterus is small, mobile, and anteverted, with no adnexal masses or cervical motion tenderness. No inguinal lymphadenopathy is present. Which of the following is the best next step in the diagnosis of this patient's condition?
Which of the following is commonly associated with this type of pelvis?

choices.text: All live vaccines under NIS can be given as per schedule
All killed vaccines under NIS can be given
Only pneumococcal vaccine should be given to the child in acute phase
Live vaccines are contraindicated in the child's sibling

questions.text: A child suffering from steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome is brought to the OD for vaccination. Which of the following is true about vaccination in this child?
questions.solution: Ans. B. All killed vaccines under NIS can be given

questions.text: A 24-year woman presents to the antenatal OPD. She is 3 months pregnant. On asking, she tells you that she has a 4-year-old son followed by a twin pregnancy which she terminated at 8 weeks. What is her obstetric formula?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) G3P1A1

 

The obstetric formula is used to record a woman’s reproductive history. It includes Gravida (G), Para (P), and Abortions (A):

 

  • Gravida (G): Refers to the total number of pregnancies, regardless of the outcome. This includes the current pregnancy. In this case, the patient is currently pregnant for the third time (one living child, one terminated twin pregnancy, and the current pregnancy), making her G3.
  • Para (P): Refers to the number of pregnancies that have reached the age of viability (generally considered around 28 weeks in many countries). The patient has had one full-term pregnancy (the 4-year-old son), making her P1.
  • Abortion (A): Refers to pregnancies that ended before viability (usually defined as before 20 weeks). Her twin pregnancy was terminated at 8 weeks, which counts as one abortion, making her A1.

 

Thus, her correct obstetric formula is G3P1A1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gravida refers to the total number of pregnancies, Para refers to the number of pregnancies that reached viability, and Abortions refers to pregnancies that ended before viability. In this case, the woman is G3P1A1: three pregnancies, one viable, and one abortion.

choices.text: Midway between the umbilicus and the pubic symphysis
Just above the pubic symphysis

Administer the diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis vaccine as scheduled
Administer only the tetanus toxoid at this time

questions.text: A 15-month-old full-term boy is brought to the clinic for a well-child examination. At age 6 months, he had a generalized seizure that lasted approximately 2 minutes within hours of receiving the diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis vaccine. He was taken to the emergency department for observation and discharged later that day. The patient has had no other seizures or medical concerns and takes no medications. His uncle has a history of childhood-onset epilepsy. The child is due for the fourth dose of the diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis vaccine. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Administer the diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis vaccine as scheduled

choices.text: Try to slip the cords over the fetal head
Clamp the cord, cut it and unwind it from around the fetal neck

questions.text: You are an intern and are conducting delivery of a 24-year G2P1. The head is delivered and undergoes restitution and external rotation. When you attempt to deliver the anterior shoulder, you notice that there are 2 tight loops of cord around the neck. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Clamp the cord, cut it and unwind it from around the fetal neck

 

The presence of tight loops of the umbilical cord around the fetal neck (nuchal cord) can pose a risk to the fetus during delivery due to compression of the cord and reduced blood flow. In this case, you have already observed two tight loops around the fetal neck, which may hinder the delivery of the shoulders and risk fetal blood loss if not addressed promptly.

The appropriate and immediate step in this situation is to clamp the cord in two places, cut it, and then unwind it from around the neck to avoid tension on the cord and prevent fetal blood loss. This ensures that the delivery can proceed safely without further complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Try to slip the cords over the fetal head: This approach can be considered for loose loops of cord around the neck, which can often be slipped over the head without much difficulty. However, in this case, the loops are described as tight, and attempting to slip them over could be dangerous or ineffective.

 

Option B. Deliver the anterior shoulder immediately: Attempting to deliver the anterior shoulder without addressing the tight loops of cord could cause excessive tension on the cord, leading to cord rupture or fetal blood loss. This is not recommended.

 

Option D. Immediately call for help: While calling for help in a complicated delivery scenario is always a good step, in this situation, the best immediate action is to clamp, cut, and unwind the cord, as delaying to wait for help could put the fetus at risk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the presence of tight loops of the umbilical cord around the fetal neck during delivery, the correct action is to clamp, cut, and unwind the cord to avoid complications such as fetal blood loss or cord snapping. This allows for a safe delivery to proceed.

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with cutaneous vasculitis and hemoptysis. HRCT is shown below. Which investigation should be performed next to help you diagnose the condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) C-ANCA

 

The most appropriate next investigation for an elderly patient presenting with cutaneous vasculitis and hemoptysis, with HRCT showing multiple large cavitating lung lesions, is C-ANCA (cytoplasmic anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibody).

 

  • C-ANCA (anti-PR3 antibody) is highly specific for Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener’s granulomatosis), which typically presents with:
    • Upper/lower respiratory tract involvement
    • Cutaneous vasculitis
    • Renal involvement
    • Cavitary lung lesions on HRCT, as seen in the image.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anti-GBM: Is specific for Goodpasture's syndrome, which presents with hematuria and pulmonary hemorrhage, but not large cavitating lesions.

 

Option C. HbsAg: Screens for hepatitis B, unrelated to the described clinical picture.

 

Option D. P-ANCA: (MPO antibody) is more common in microscopic polyangiitis and eosinophilic granulomatosis.

questions.text: A 8-year-old boy weighing 30 Kgs has been posted for surgical resection of a tumor. What is the daily maintenance fluid required for this child while he's NPO?

A 23-year-old woman presents with vaginal discharge. There is no foul smell or associated pruritis. On examination, there is white discharge and the cervix and vagina are normal. A pH is done which is 4 and a vaginal smear shows the following. What is the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Physiological discharge

 

Physiological vaginal discharge is common in reproductive-age women due to estrogenic stimulation. It is usually white or mucoid, non-foul smelling, and not associated with pruritus or inflammation. The vagina and cervix appear normal. Vaginal pH is in the normal acidic range (3.8–4.5), and smear shows only normal epithelial cells with lactobacilli. No pathogens or clue cells are present. This requires reassurance, not treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bacterial vaginosis: Discharge is thin, gray-white, foul-smelling, and pH >4.5. Microscopy shows clue cells and a positive “whiff test” with KOH.

 

Option B. Trichomonas vaginalis: Discharge is frothy, yellow-green, with foul odor and pruritus. Vaginal pH >4.5. Microscopy shows motile flagellated protozoa.

 

Option C. Candidiasis: Discharge is thick, curdy white, with severe vulval itching. Vaginal pH remains normal (≤4.5), but smear shows budding yeast or pseudohyphae, not just normal epithelial cells.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman is evaluated in the postpartum unit for vaginal bleeding. Two hours ago, she underwent an uncomplicated spontaneous vaginal delivery with an estimated blood loss of 250 mL. Bleeding was initially minimal, but there is now profuse vaginal bleeding, and the patient's perineal pad is soaked with blood and large clots. The patient has chronic hypertension that has been managed throughout this pregnancy with labetalol. Blood pressure is 148/102 mm Hg and pulse is 110/min. On pelvic examination, the uterine fundus is soft. All of the following should be done next except?
What is this maneuver?
You have been called to declare the brain death of a 12-year-old child in the ICU. Which of the following is not seen in brain death?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Decorticate and decerebrate posturing

questions.text: Considering the components of the APGAR score, which of the following is not a factor included in this assessment tool?

A 30 year P1 with a last menstrual period 10 days ago presents to the emergency with complaints of worsening right pelvic pain. She says that she had sudden onset of sharp pain after bending over to pick up her child. The pain did not respond to acetaminophen and has intermittently worsened during the past several hours. She also had 2 episodes of vomiting.  On examination, there is abdominal guarding. Transvaginal sonography demonstrates an 8-cm enlarged right ovary. There is high impedance arterial flow of the ovary on colour Doppler. These findings are most consistent with which of the following clinical diagnoses?

A 39-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 1, at 38 weeks gestation, comes to the office for a routine prenatal visit. The patient feels well and reports normal fetal activity. Last week, she had nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea for 24 hours, but she has been able to eat and drink normally for the past several days. For the past 2 days, the patient has had increased clear vaginal discharge with irregular, painful contractions but no vaginal bleeding. Temperature is 99.6°F (37.6°C), blood pressure is 132/86 mm Hg, and pulse is 96/ min. The uterus is nontender and the fundal height is 34 cm. Fetal heart tones are 135/ min. Fetal ultrasound shows a cephalic fetus, measuring at the 50th percentile for gestational age, and an amniotic fluid index of 2 cm (normal: >5 cm). Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's amniotic fluid level?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rupture of membranes

 

Diagnosis: Rupture of membranes (ROM) resulting in oligohydramnios.

 

Key Reasoning:

 

  • History of clear vaginal fluid leakage → strongly suggests amniotic fluid loss.
  • AFI of 2 cm → diagnostic of oligohydramnios.
  • Uterus smaller than expected (fundal height 34 cm at 38 weeks) → due to loss of amniotic fluid volume.
  • Fetus with normal growth and heart rate → no placental insufficiency or infection.
  • Nontender uterus, afebrile → no chorioamnionitis or abruption.

 

Thus, prelabor rupture of membranes (PROM) is the most likely cause.

 

Pathophysiology: Amniotic fluid is produced mainly by fetal urine and resorbed by fetal swallowing. When membranes rupture, fluid leaks through the cervix and vagina. Leads to decreased AFI (<5 cm) and risk of cord compression or infection.

 

Supporting Clinical Features:

 

 

Confirmatory Tests for Rupture of Membranes:

 

  1. Speculum examination: Pooling of clear fluid in posterior fornix.
  2. Nitrazine test: Turns blue (alkaline) due to amniotic fluid pH (~7.0–7.5).
  3. Fern test: Microscopic “fern-like” pattern due to crystallized amniotic fluid.
  4. Ultrasound: Confirms low AFI consistent with fluid loss.

 

Management:

 

  • At term (≥37 weeks): Induce labor to prevent infection.
  • At 34–36 weeks: Consider delivery after assessing fetal lung maturity.

 

At <34 weeks: Conservative management with corticosteroids and antibiotics if no infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fetal congenital infection: Causes hydrops fetalis, hepatosplenomegaly, or polyhydramnios, not isolated oligohydramnios.

 

Option B. Maternal dehydration: May cause mild, transient oligohydramnios, but would resolve after rehydration. The patient is currently well hydrated and has persistent low AFI with fluid leakage.

 

Option C. Normal gestational age variant: AFI normally decreases slightly late in pregnancy but never to 2 cm. AFI <5 cm is pathologic and requires evaluation for ROM or placental insufficiency.

choices.text: Expectant management with close monitoring and regular ultrasounds
Initiation of antenatal corticosteroids and scheduled cesarean section at 37 weeks gestation

During her routine ultrasound examination, the radiologist reports findings suggestive of placenta accreta. The patient has no symptoms at present. Which of the following is the most appropriate management option for this patient?

The girl has grown 10.1 cm in the last year; her height and weight are at the 70th percentile for age. There is no breast bud development. External pelvic examination shows the clitoris protruding from the clitoral hood and bilateral masses in the labia majora. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 29-year-old woman, G2P1 presents at 18 weeks gestation with a history of a previous preterm birth at 28 weeks. She is concerned about the risk of another preterm delivery in the current pregnancy. On examination, her cervix is found to be dilated to 2 cm and effaced. She has no contractions at the time of evaluation. Fetal ultrasound shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient to reduce the risk of preterm birth?

A 31-year-old woman, gravida 3 para 2, at 40 weeks gestation is in active labor. The patient has had a normal prenatal course. Her first pregnancy was an uncomplicated term vaginal delivery. Her second pregnancy ended with an emergent cesarean delivery for a nonreassuring fetal heart rate pattern. Spontaneous rupture of the membranes occurred 15 minutes ago with blood-tinged amniotic fluid. Blood pressure is 124/76 mm Hg, pulse is 78/ min, and respirations are 18/min. On pelvic examination, the cervix is 6 cm dilated and 80% effaced, and the fetal presenting part is at +1 station. The fetal heart rate tracing is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this fetal heart rate pattern?
Which alternative method can be used for the procedure shown in the image below?
Which of the following decreases in pregnancy?

A woman presented to the clinic with heavy, painful menses that have worsened over the past year. On pelvic examination the uterus is enlarged and tender. USG is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Adenomyosis

 

  • Adenomyosis is characterized by the presence of endometrial glands and stroma within the myometrium.
  • This leads to diffuse uterine enlargement, dysmenorrhea, and menorrhagia due to cyclical bleeding within the myometrium.

 

Key Diagnostic Features:

 

Clinical Findings:

 

  • Age group: Typically multiparous women aged 35–50 years.
  • Symptoms:
    • Heavy, prolonged menstrual bleeding (menorrhagia)
    • Painful menstruation (secondary dysmenorrhea)
    • Diffuse uterine tenderness and enlargement (“boggy uterus”)

 

Ultrasound Findings (as in the image):

 

  • Diffuse thickening of the myometrium
  • Heterogeneous echotexture
  • Fan-shaped / “Venetian blind” acoustic shadowing
  • Poorly defined endo-myometrial junction
  • Small myometrial cysts (due to trapped endometrial glands)
  • No well-defined mass, unlike leiomyoma

 

Pathophysiology: Caused by invasion of endometrial tissue into the myometrium through the basal layer of the endometrium. Leads to myometrial hypertrophy and increased uterine size. Estrogen-dependent condition, often coexisting with endometriosis or fibroids.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polyps: Focal endometrial overgrowths. Cause intermenstrual spotting or irregular bleeding, not diffuse uterine tenderness or enlargement. USG shows focal echogenic mass within endometrial cavity, not diffuse myometrial heterogeneity.

 

Option B. Leiomyoma: Benign smooth muscle tumor (fibroid). Uterus is firm, irregular, often non-tender. Ultrasound shows well-defined hypoechoic mass with acoustic shadowing, unlike diffuse pattern in adenomyosis.

 

Option D. Endometrial hyperplasia: Caused by unopposed estrogen stimulation. Presents with irregular or postmenopausal bleeding, not pain. Uterus is normal in size; USG shows uniformly thickened endometrium.

questions.solution: Ans. D) If mother is IgG positive for CMV, the child is unlikely to develop infection

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the OPD for follow-up of breast biopsy that confirmed high-grade malignant features. Family history is significant for ovarian cancer in her mother, who died at age 50. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the BRCA2 gene. The patient is scheduled to begin chemotherapy and is advised to avoid pregnancy. Which of the following is the best contraceptive option for this patient?

choices.text: 2,00,000 IU immediately, followed by same dose after 24 hours
1,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose after 1 week
1,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose after 24 hours and after a week
2,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose 24 hours later and after 2 weeks

questions.text: In the case of a 2-year-old baby diagnosed with keratomalacia as shown in the image below, what is the prescribed dosage of vitamin A?
questions.solution: Ans. D. 2,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose 24 hours later and after 2 weeks

questions.text: All of the following are true about theophylline except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Deactivation of histone deacetylase: Anti-inflammatory

 

Theophylline actually activates histone deacetylase, which contributes to its anti-inflammatory effects; deactivation would be incorrect.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. PDE 4 inhibition: Bronchodilation: Correct, PDE4 inhibition leads to bronchodilation in airway smooth muscles.

 

Option C. PDE 3 inhibition: Cardiac effects: True, PDE3 inhibition affects cardiac contractility and heart rate.

 

Option D. Adenosine antagonism: Diuresis: Correct; blocking adenosine receptors promotes diuresis.

choices.text: Take the vaccine but avoid travel

questions.text: A 28-year-old  doctor working for Medicine sans frontiers is travelling to several countries of Africa. She is 12 weeks pregnant and visits for yellow fever vaccination which is mandatory for travel to some countries in Africa. As it’s a live vaccine, she is worried if it is safe for her. What will you advise?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Take the vaccine and travel

 

The yellow fever vaccine is a live-attenuated vaccine. In general, live vaccines are avoided during pregnancy due to theoretical risks to the fetus. However, the yellow fever vaccine is an exception when travel to endemic or high-risk areas is unavoidable. In such cases, the benefit of vaccination outweighs the theoretical risk.

 

The risks associated with yellow fever infection in a pregnant woman (e.g., high mortality rates, severe disease) are much greater than the minimal, unproven risks from the vaccine.

 

Key points about vaccines in pregnancy:

 

  • Safe live vaccine in pregnancy (if indicated): Yellow fever vaccine (when travel to endemic areas is essential).
  • Avoided live vaccines: MMR (measles, mumps, rubella), varicella, smallpox, and live influenza.
  • Killed or inactivated vaccines that are safe: Rabies, hepatitis B, COVID-19 vaccines, tetanus-diphtheria-pertussis (Tdap), and inactivated influenza vaccine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases where travel to yellow fever endemic areas is essential, the yellow fever vaccine can be safely administered during pregnancy as the benefits far outweigh the theoretical risks.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department due to continuous vomiting, diarrhea, and high fever for a day. The patient also has a severe headache that is unrelieved by acetaminophen.  The patient spent the last 3 months in Southeast Asia and returned yesterday on an international flight. She is currently on the fifth day of her menstrual period and has had to use both tampons and pads due to heavy bleeding. Temperature is 39.4 C (103 F), blood pressure is 80/40 mm Hg, and pulse is 124/min. Physical examination reveals a diaphoretic woman with dry mucous membranes. There is no nuchal rigidity. An erythematous macular rash covers the entire body, including the palms and soles. Which of the following microorganisms is most likely responsible for this patient's symptoms?

A 5-year-old child is brought to the Pediatrics OPD with eczematous rash over the skin. His past history reveals that he had recurrent skin infections and pneumonia in the past six months. Hemogram reveals low platelet count. Which of the following investigations should be done in this patient?
What is the average duration of lochia discharge in a puerperal woman?
What is the use of the instrument given below?

A 2-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of cyanosis. The infant has had similar episodes during feeding and crying, but these resolved quickly. On examination, the infant is ill-appearing, agitated, cyanotic, and tachypneic. Cardiac auscultation reveals a grade 2/6 crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border and a single second heart sound. The patient is placed in a knee-chest position immediately. This maneuver improves the patient's condition predominantly by which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Increased systemic vascular resistance

questions.text: A 4-year-old male presents with coarse facial features, enlarged liver and spleen, and a progressive decline in cognitive abilities. Urine analysis reveals the presence of glycosaminoglycans. Corneal clouding was absent. Which enzyme deficiency is most likely responsible for the symptoms observed in this patient?

A 29-year-old woman with ulcerative colitis is brought to the emergency department after a syncopal episode while getting out of bed. Yesterday she developed right-sided abdominal pain which has spread across the lower abdomen over the past few hours. She also noticed a blood stain on her underwear after the syncopal episode. The patient was diagnosed with ulcerative colitis 3 years ago and is in remission with oral mesalamine therapy. Her last menstrual period was 8 weeks ago. The patient uses condoms intermittently for contraception. Her temperature is 37 C (98 F), blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg, and pulse is 125/min. She has diffuse lower abdominal pain with rebound tenderness and voluntary guarding. Pelvic examination shows cervical motion and right adnexal tenderness, no masses are palpated. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
Following delivery of a twin pregnancy which was unbooked, the placenta is examined and is as shown. What is the likely time of splitting of the embryo?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) After the 8th day

 

The image shows a single placenta with no intertwin membrane, indicating a monochorionic monoamniotic (MCMA) twin pregnancy. MCMA twins share a single placenta and an amniotic sac because the embryo splits after the 8th day of fertilization, by which time the chorion and amnion have already formed.

 

Key Points for Twin Types:

 

  1. Dizygotic twins (two separate embryos): Always dichorionic diamniotic (DCDA).
  2. Monozygotic twins (one embryo that splits):
    • Day 1–3 (early split): Dichorionic diamniotic (DCDA) twins.
    • Day 4–7: Monochorionic diamniotic (MCDA) twins (shared placenta, separate amniotic sacs).
    • Day 8–12: Monochorionic monoamniotic (MCMA) twins (shared placenta and amniotic sac).
    • After day 12: Incomplete splitting leads to conjoined twins.

 

In this case, since the placenta is single and there is no separating membrane, it is consistent with a monochorionic monoamniotic (MCMA) twin pregnancy, indicating splitting after the 8th day.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Within 72 hours: Splitting at this stage results in dichorionic diamniotic (DCDA) twins.

 

Option B. 3rd to 7th day: Splitting during this period results in monochorionic diamniotic (MCDA) twins, where a thin membrane separates the amniotic sacs.

 

Option D. The embryo didn’t split: This refers to a singleton pregnancy or conjoined twins if the split was incomplete.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In monozygotic twinning, the timing of embryo splitting determines whether twins will be dichorionic diamniotic (DCDA), monochorionic diamniotic (MCDA), monochorionic monoamniotic (MCMA), or conjoined twins. In MCMA pregnancies, the embryo splits after the 8th day, resulting in one placenta and one amniotic sac.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is brought to the OPD by her mother for evaluation of abdominal pain.  The patient has had no fevers, diarrhea, or bloody stools. She first noticed an erythematous, macular rash over her daughter's legs and back 2 days ago that has become darker and more confluent today. The patient has a history of moderate persistent asthma for which she uses an inhaled fluticasone inhaler daily and albuterol as needed for wheezing. The right knee is mildly swollen and painful with passive range of motion. Which of the following glomerular abnormalities is most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Mesangial deposition of IgA

choices.text: The distance from midpoint of sacral promontory to the upper most margin of the symphysis pubis.
The shortest distance between the sacral promontory and the symphysis pubis.

questions.solution: Ans. A. The distance from midpoint of sacral promontory to the upper most margin of tthe symphysis pubis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman, gravida 4 para 2 aborta 1, comes to the emergency department at 24 weeks gestation with vaginal bleeding that started after intercourse. The patient woke up in a pool of bright red blood and continues to soak through a pad every hour. She has not had routine prenatal care during this pregnancy but had a sonogram at 8 weeks gestation that showed a singleton intrauterine pregnancy. The patient has had 2 cesarean deliveries at term and a cervical conization earlier this year. She smokes a pack of cigarettes daily.  Blood pressure is 124/78 mm Hg and pulse is 92/min. Fetal monitoring shows a baseline of 140/min, accelerations, absent decelerations, and moderate variability. On speculum examination, there are large clots in the vaginal vault, a closed cervix, and active bleeding from the os. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
Match the following developmental milestones:

choices.text: Prior to the removal of Placenta accreta in Multiparous woman
Patient diagnosed with calcified and pedunculated submucous fibroids

questions.text: As a senior resident in the OBG department, you would consider uterine artery embolization as a treatment option in all of the following cases except:
questions.solution: Ans. C. Patient diagnosed with calcified and pedunculated submucous fibroids

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman is evaluated at her 32nd week of pregnancy. Laboratory results are as follows:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Normal pregnancy

 

These lab findings represent normal physiological changes in pregnancy.
 

Let’s interpret each finding:

 

1. Arterial blood gas (ABG) values:

 

  • pH: 7.45 → slightly alkalotic but within normal range
  • PaCO₂: 30 mmHg → low (normal 35–45 mmHg)
  • HCO₃⁻: 20 mEq/L → compensatory decrease
  • Interpretation: Chronic respiratory alkalosis with renal compensation

 

Mechanism: 

 

  • In pregnancy, progesterone stimulates the respiratory center → mild hyperventilation → ↓ PaCO₂ → mild respiratory alkalosis. 
  • The kidneys compensate by excreting bicarbonate, maintaining near-normal pH.

 

2. Hemoglobin (11 g/dL): Physiologic hemodilution (physiologic anemia of pregnancy) due to plasma volume expansion > RBC mass increase.

 

3. PaO₂ (110 mmHg): Slightly higher than nonpregnant range (due to hyperventilation and increased alveolar ventilation).

 

4. BUN (5 mg/dL) and Creatinine (0.6 mg/dL): Lowered due to increased renal plasma flow and GFR in pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anemia: Hb is 11 g/dL, which is normal for pregnancy.

 

Option B. Hyperemesis gravidarum: Causes metabolic alkalosis due to vomiting (↑ HCO₃⁻, not ↓).

 

Option D. Preeclampsia: Would show elevated BP, proteinuria, and often elevated creatinine, not low.

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida is in labor. The baseline fetal heart rate (FHR) is 110 bpm. All of the following are possible causes of fetal bradycardia except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Maternal fever

 

Normal FHR: 110–160 beats per minute.

 

  • FHR <110 bpm for >10 minutes = fetal bradycardia.
  • Bradycardia may be due to maternal, fetal, or drug-related causes that decrease fetal oxygenation or vagal stimulation.

 

Causes of Fetal Bradycardia:

 

1. Maternal causes:

 

  • Hypotension (e.g., after epidural or hemorrhage) → reduced uteroplacental flow
  • Hypothermia → reduced fetal metabolism and heart rate
  • Hypoglycemia → decreased fetal metabolic activity
  • Drugs: Beta-blockers (e.g., labetalol, propranolol) → transplacental effect on fetal heart

 

2. Fetal causes:

 

  • Hypoxia or acidosis (most common cause in labor)
  • Umbilical cord compression or cord prolapse → vagal stimulation
  • Congenital heart block (especially with maternal lupus or Sjögren’s syndrome — anti-Ro/SSA antibodies)

 

Option D (Maternal fever) is Incorrect: Maternal fever causes fetal tachycardia, not bradycardia. The mechanism: increased maternal and fetal metabolism → increased FHR (>160 bpm). Commonly seen with chorioamnionitis or maternal infection.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 1, at 38 weeks gestation comes to the emergency department due to severe abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. The patient had an ultrasound at 8 weeks gestation for vaginal spotting but has not otherwise received prenatal care this pregnancy. Her prior pregnancy two and a half years ago ended in a classical cesarean delivery at 24 weeks gestation for placental abruption. The patient smokes a pack of cigarettes daily and uses cocaine multiple times a week. Blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg and pulse is 130/min. The abdomen is tender and has an irregular mass; no contractions are palpated. Bright red blood is noted on the perineal pad. Fetal heart tracing shows multiple prolonged decelerations to 100/min. Which of the following risk factors most likely contributed to this patient's presentation?

choices.text: Increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine
Increased indirect bilirubin, absent urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine
Increased direct bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine
Increased direct bilirubin, absent urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in physiological jaundice?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine

questions.text: Anti-D vaccine is not given in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Intrauterine transfusion at 28 weeks

questions.text: Which of the following options is incorrectly matched?
A woman presented in her 8th week of pregnancy seeking MTP. The appropriate dosage of Misoprostol (administered by mucosal route) would be:

A 22-year-old woman comes to the clinic for a routine examination. She is a gymnast. Three months ago, she sustained a vulvar contusion during a competition but otherwise she has been healthy. The patient is sexually active with a male partner and uses an intrauterine device for contraception. She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. Examination shows a mobile, soft, nontender, flesh-coloured, 2-cm cystic mass at the 4 o'clock position at the base of the left labium majus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bartholin duct cyst

 

Bartholin duct cyst is the most likely diagnosis based on:

  • Location: 4 o’clock or 8 o’clock position on the posterior aspect of the vaginal introitus (base of labium majus)
  • Character: Soft, mobile, cystic, and usually non-tender unless infected
  • Size: Often 1–4 cm
  • Cause: Obstruction of the Bartholin gland duct, leading to retention of glandular secretions and cyst formation
  • Predisposing factors: Trauma or inflammation (in this case, vulvar contusion could have blocked the duct)

 

Pathophysiology: 

 

  • Bartholin glands (paired glands) are located at 4 and 8 o’clock positions of the vaginal opening. 
  • Their ducts open into the vestibule and provide lubrication during sexual activity. 
  • Trauma, inflammation, or infection can block the duct → accumulation of mucus → Bartholin duct cyst. 
  • If infected, it can form a Bartholin abscess (tender, erythematous, fluctuant swelling).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Condylomata acuminata: Caused by Human Papillomavirus (HPV 6, 11). Appear as multiple, firm, cauliflower-like or verrucous growths, not cystic or fluid-filled. Usually on the vulva, perineum, or anus, not localized to a single cystic lesion.

 

Option C. Gartner duct cyst: Remnant of the Wolffian (mesonephric) duct. Located on the lateral wall of the vagina, not at the labial base. Typically felt as a cyst along the anterolateral vaginal wall, superior to the Bartholin glands.

 

Option D. Hematoma: Occurs acutely after trauma with painful, tender, and often discolored swelling. This patient’s mass is nontender and chronic (3 months), excluding a hematoma.

questions.text: What is the management of the lesion described in the last question?

Which of the following instruments are used in the caesarean section?

 

  1. Bard-Parker blade
  2. Doyen's retractor
  3. Cusco's speculum
  4. Allis forceps
  5. Shirodkar's uterine clamp
  6. Green Armytage forceps

A woman undergoes a radical hysterectomy with bilateral pelvic and para-aortic lymph node dissection for a 2-cm squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix". On final pathologic evaluation of the surgical specimen, the parametria are positive for cancer involvement. Based on these findings, which International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics (FIGO) clinical stage is she assigned?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IB2

 

Cervical cancer staging is primarily clinical and based on physical examination and imaging, not on surgical pathology findings. Even if parametrium involvement is found on histopathology, the clinical stage does not change. The clinical examination determines the initial stage:

 

  • Stage 1B: Cancer confined to the cervix, visible, or greater than 5 mm in depth.
    • 1B1: Tumor ≤ 2 cm
    • 1B2: Tumor 2-4 cm
    • 1B3: Tumor > 4 cm

 

Since the tumor is 2 cm (classified as 1B2), the involvement of the parametrium on histology does not change the clinical stage.

 

FIGO Staging Overview:

 

  1. Stage 1: Confined to the cervix
  2. Stage 2: Involves the upper two-thirds of the vagina or parametrium but not the pelvic sidewall
  3. Stage 3: Involves the lower one-third of the vagina, pelvic sidewall, or lymph nodes
    • 3C: Involves lymph nodes (based on imaging or histology)
  4. Stage 4: Distant metastasis

 

Key Points:

 

  • Clinical staging remains unchanged regardless of postoperative pathology findings.
  • Involvement of lymph nodes detected on imaging or confirmed histopathology is classified as Stage 3C in the updated FIGO classification.
  • Surgery is typically reserved for early-stage disease (up to 2A1), beyond which chemoradiation is the standard of care.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cervical cancer staging is determined clinically, with imaging modalities such as MRI or CT aiding the process. The findings of parametrium involvement on histopathology do not alter the clinical staging, which remains 1B2 for a 2 cm lesion confined to the cervix.

choices.text: Increased number of theca lutein cysts

questions.text: All of the following can be indicators of choriocarcinoma except:
questions.solution: Ans. A. Increased number of theca lutein cysts

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 1, is seen in the hospital on postoperative day 2 due to lower abdominal pain, chills, and pain with sitting. She came to the hospital when she had no contractions a day after spontaneous rupture of membranes. After a 26-hour induction of labor, she had a primary cesarean delivery for arrest of descent. The breasts are full but have no erythema or fluctuant masses. The uterine fundus is firm and tender to palpation. There is scant serosanguineous drainage from the lower aspect of the incision. Pelvic examination shows a small amount of blood on the perineal pad with mildly foul-smelling discharge. Which of the following is the best regimen for treating this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Clindamycin plus gentamicin

 

  • This patient has postpartum endometritis, a polymicrobial uterine infection that commonly occurs after cesarean delivery, especially following prolonged rupture of membranes and labor induction.

 

Key Clinical Features of Postpartum Endometritis:

 

  • Timing: Usually within 2–10 days after delivery
  • Symptoms: Fever, chills, Lower abdominal or pelvic pain, Uterine tenderness on palpation, Foul-smelling lochia (vaginal discharge)
  • Physical findings: Uterus firm (not boggy, ruling out atony) and tender; incision may show mild drainage but main source is uterine infection.

 

Causative Organisms:

 

  • Polymicrobial infection including:
    • Ureaplasma, Mycoplasma hominis
    • Gardnerellavaginalis
    • Peptostreptococcus, Bacteroides
    • E. coli, Group B Streptococcus

 

  • Because of this mixed aerobic and anaerobic flora, broad-spectrum coverage is required.
  • Treatment:
    • Empiric antibiotic regimen: Clindamycin + Gentamicin
    • Rationale:
      • Clindamycin: Excellent coverage for anaerobes and gram-positive cocci.
      • Gentamicin: Covers gram-negative organisms. This combination provides broad-spectrum coverage against nearly all common postpartum pathogens.
    • Continue IV therapy until the patient is afebrile for ≥24 hours and clinically improved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ceftriaxone: Covers mainly gram-negative and some gram-positive bacteria, but not anaerobes. Inadequate for polymicrobial uterine infection.

 

Option B. Ceftriaxone plus azithromycin: Used for pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis, not postpartum endometritis. Fails to cover the typical postpartum anaerobic flora.

 

Option D. Dicloxacillin: Used for mastitis (Staphylococcus aureus), not uterine infection. No role in postpartum endometritis.

questions.text: The hormone that does not play a role in the growth of the fetus is:

choices.text: Change the fluid to normal saline
Continue the surgery with careful monitoring of fluid status
Give furosemide to the patient and continue surgery

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady with submucosal fibroid was undergoing myomectomy. The surgeon was using 1.5% glycine as irrigating fluid for the cavity. During the surgery, the nurse informs that there is a 500ml deficit of the irrigating fluid. What is the next step to be done?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Continue the surgery with careful monitoring of fluid status

questions.text: A patient is suspected of having an inherited disorder. Pedigree analysis shows the following pattern. This patient most likely has which of the following conditions?

choices.text: 18-year-old with amenorrhea and an elevated prolactin level
16-year-old with amenorrhea with normal secondary sexual characters and no mullerian structures on sonography
16-year-old with amenorrhea with normal secondary sexual characters and uterus seen on imaging

questions.text: In which of the following patients is a karyotype most likely needed?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 16-year-old with amenorrhea with normal secondary sexual characters and no mullerian structures on sonography 

 

In a 16-year-old with primary amenorrhea and normal secondary sexual characteristics but absence of Mullerian structures (uterus, fallopian tubes, and upper two-thirds of the vagina), a karyotype is essential to differentiate between two primary conditions:

 

  1. Mullerian Agenesis (Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser Syndrome - MRKH):
    • Karyotype: 46, XX
    • Normal ovarian function (producing estrogen), leading to the development of secondary sexual characteristics.
    • No uterus or upper vaginal structures due to Mullerian agenesis.
  2. Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (AIS):
    • Karyotype: 46, XY
    • Complete androgen insensitivity results in the inability of the body to respond to androgens.
    • Secondary sexual characteristics develop due to peripheral conversion of testosterone to estrogen.
    • Testes are present (may be intra-abdominal), but Mullerian structures regress due to Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) produced by Sertoli cells.

 

A karyotype test helps differentiate between these conditions, making it essential in this clinical scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 20-year-old with amenorrhea and hirsutism: This is likely PCOS or another hyperandrogenic condition, where karyotyping is not necessary.

 

Option B. 18-year-old with amenorrhea and an elevated prolactin level: This indicates hyperprolactinemia (e.g., due to a prolactinoma or hypothyroidism), where a prolactin assay and imaging, not a karyotype, are the key diagnostic tools.

 

Option D. 16-year-old with amenorrhea, normal secondary sexual characters, and uterus seen on imaging: A functional or structural outflow obstruction (e.g., transverse vaginal septum or imperforate hymen) or constitutional delay of puberty is more likely. Karyotyping is not typically required.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A karyotype is necessary to differentiate between Mullerian agenesis (MRKH) and Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (AIS) in a patient with primary amenorrhea, normal secondary sexual characteristics, and absence of Mullerian structures. These conditions have different genetic backgrounds (46,XX for MRKH and 46,XY for AIS), which guides appropriate management.

choices.text: Observe and reexamine the cervix in 2 hours

questions.text: A 32-year-old primigravida comes to the hospital at 28 weeks gestation due to painful contractions that began 2 hours ago and are currently occurring every 5 minutes. The patient reports frequent fetal movement and no leakage of fluid or vaginal bleeding. Her temperature is 37 C (98.7 F), blood pressure is 125/60 mm Hg, and pulse is 80/min. An amniocentesis is performed, and a fetal karyotype analysis is ordered; the results are shown in the image below:

The boy played basketball every weekend without any symptoms and was in his usual state of health prior to this event. Family history is significant for a maternal uncle who died at age 25 for unknown reasons. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation is unsuccessful and the patient is pronounced dead.   1. Hyponatremia
  2. Hypomagnesemia
  3. Hypocalcemia

A 18-year-old girl with primary amenorrhea, no breast development and Prader 3 genitalia was found to have raised FSH. Her karyotype revealed 45 X0/46 XY and an ultrasound revealed Mullerian structures with poorly visualized gonads. What would be the next line of management?

A 49-year-old woman, gravida 5 para 5, comes to the OPD due to involuntary, intermittent loss of urine over the past 5 months. The patient is an avid jogger and now must wear absorbent pads while jogging.  Three years ago, the patient was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus, which is treated with metformin.  The patient loses a small amount of urine when asked to cough. Postvoid residual urine volume is 40 mL. Clean-catch urinalysis results are as follows:

 

Blood: negative

 

Glucose: negative

 

Leukocyte esterase: negative

 

Nitrites: negative

 

White blood cells: 3-5/hpf

 

Serum hemoglobin A1c is 7.7%. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
A 3-year-old child was brought to the OPD for a regular check-up. His growth chart shows his BMI between 85th and 95th percentile. Which of the following categories would you place him in?

A newborn girl is evaluated in the delivery room for respiratory distress. The patient was born 15 minutes ago by spontaneous vaginal delivery at 37 weeks gestation to a mother who received no prenatal care. Temperature is 37 C (98.6 F), pulse is 176/min, and respirations are 70/min. Pulse oximetry is 82% on room air. Physical examination shows grunting; subcostal and suprasternal retractions; and cyanosis of the lips and tongue. The chest appears rounded and the abdomen appears flat. Auscultation reveals absent breath sounds on the left and clear breath sounds on the right. Heart sounds are loudest in the right chest. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?

choices.text: Obstructed hemivagina and ipsilateral renal anomaly (OHVIRA) syndrome

questions.text: A 13-year-old female presents with increasing abdominal pain. She has begun appropriate pubertal development, although menarche has not occurred. During examination, a central abdominopelvic mass is appreciated. The MR imaging results are shown. Which of the following congenital anomalies is most likely present?

A preterm neonate, who was born via spontaneous vaginal delivery at 36 weeks gestation, did not cry at birth. Despite positive pressure ventilation (PPV) and intubation, the child did not improve. Therefore, chest compressions were initiated. What is the criterion for initiating chest compressions?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Heart rate less than 60

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman is referred to the gyn OPD with an incidental finding of b/l solid ovarian masses on an ultrasound. She is a known case of breast cancer treated a few years back. A biopsy of the masses shows the following image. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Krukenberg tumor

 

A Krukenberg tumor is a metastatic adenocarcinoma of the ovary, most commonly originating from the stomach (the primary malignancy is usually a gastric adenocarcinoma), although it can also originate from the breast or other gastrointestinal organs. The hallmark histological feature is the presence of signet ring cells, which are characterized by a large cytoplasmic mucin vacuole that pushes the nucleus to the periphery, giving the appearance of a "signet ring."

 

In this case, the bilateral solid ovarian masses in a patient with a history of breast cancer are consistent with Krukenberg tumors. The bilateral nature and the biopsy showing signet ring cells strongly point to this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dysgerminoma: Dysgerminomas are germ cell tumors of the ovary and usually occur in younger women. They do not show signet ring cells on histology. Instead, they have large polygonal cells with clear cytoplasm and prominent nucleoli.

 

Option B. Endometrioid carcinoma: This is a primary ovarian epithelial tumor with glandular structures resembling endometrial tissue. It is not associated with signet ring cells and typically presents as a unilocular cystic mass.

 

Option D. Granulosa cell tumor: Granulosa cell tumors are sex cord-stromal tumors that secrete estrogen and can present with features of endometrial hyperplasia or bleeding. Histologically, they show Call-Exner bodies (small spaces filled with eosinophilic fluid surrounded by granulosa cells), not signet ring cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A Krukenberg tumor is a metastatic ovarian tumor that most commonly arises from the stomach and is histologically characterized by signet ring cells. It is often bilateral and may also arise from breast cancer metastases.

questions.text:
A 4-day-old, full-term boy is brought to the office for his first visit after an uncomplicated vaginal delivery and unremarkable newborn nursery course. The patient's mother, gravida 1 para 1, has blood type A positive, and prenatal laboratory results and ultrasound were normal. Birth weight was 3.4 kg and length was 48.5 cm. He has been exclusively breastfed since birth and nurses for 10 minutes on each breast every 4 hours. He has 2 wet diapers each day but has not voided today. He has scleral icterus and jaundice of the face, chest, and abdomen.

 

Laboratory results are as follows:

 

Total bilirubin 14 mg/dL

 

Direct bilirubin 0.9 mg/dL

 

Which of the following is the most likely cause of this infant's hyperbilirubinemia?
